bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: During this time, lawyers were admitted to the bar by the judges of the courts in which they intended to practice. Applicants were required to apply to the Court of Appeals for certification to take the Bar Exam. The court required written recommendations from practicing lawyers pertaining to the applicant's knowledge and character.

Beginning in 1910, the Virginia Board of Bar Examiners licensed lawyers. The Board was established by an act of the General Assembly approved March 14, 1910. The act provided for the appointment by the Governor of a Board of Examiners to license lawyers. The Board served under the auspices of the Supreme Court of Appeals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains letters to the Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia from individuals requesting certification to take the bar exam, 1897-1909, in order to obtain a license to practice law in a particular locality and court. Most of the files include the required recommendations from practicing lawyers.
The letters are arranged chronologically by year, and alphabetically within each year.
The collection also contains two folders of correspondence, 1905-1929, from attorneys licensed to practice in other states requesting licenses to practice in Virginia.
